text:
Lexington Avenue, east side, north from 49th Street, showing  at N. E. corner old Biblical Seminary Building.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.  October 29, 1927.

49th Street, north side, from Lexington to Park Avenues. The Adams Express Company on Lexington Avenue has already been demolished, and the power plant in the centre of this picture will soon go to make way for the new Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
July 30, 1929.
P. L. Sperr..

49th Street, north side, west from but not including Lexington
Astoria Hotel.
March 4, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

Lexington Avenue, west side, south from E. 49th Street, as viewed from the Hotel Beverly at the N. E. corner of 50th Street. Constructional details seen are for the new Waldorf-Astoria. Across same eppears the 14 story Barclay. This is at the S. W. corner. Above this is the towering Grand Central Building. To the left of the latter are the dim outlines of the Lincoln
and the Chanin Buildings.
May 3, 1930
P. L. Sperr  Views 1,2

Lexington Avenue, west side, south from E. 49th Street, as viewed from the Hotel Beverly at the N. E. corner of 50th Street. Constructional details seen are for the new Waldorf-Astoria. Across same eppears the 14 story Barclay. This is at the S. W. corner. Above this is the towering Grand Central Building. To the left of the latter are the dim outlines of the Lincoln
and the Chanin Buildings.
May 3, 1930
P. L. Sperr  Views 1,2
Lexington Avenue, at East 49th Street showing the new Hotel Waldorf Astoria  site, as viewed south eastward from No 485 Madison Avenue (S.E. corner of 52nd Street).
Lexington Avenue, at East 49th Street showing the new Hotel Waldorf Astoria  site, as viewed south eastward from No 485 Madison Avenue (S.E. corner of 52nd Street).

Lexington Avenue, west side, from 49th to 50th Streets, showing the upper end of the Grand Central railroad yards in the block where the new Hotel Waldorf-Astoria is being erected. The cars in the right foreground are directly below the site of the Adams Express Building, which has just been demolished. The rest of the block was occupied by the railroad power plant and Y. M. C. A.
March 4, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

144-150 East 49th Street, south side, between Lexington and
Third Avenues.
About 1924.
Underwood & Underwood.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

Lexington Avenue, west side, south from E. 49th Street, as viewed from the Hotel Beverly at the N.E. corner of 50th Street. Constructional details seen are for the new Waldorf-Astoria. Across same appears the 14 story Barclay. This is at the S.W. corner. Above this is the towering Grand Central Building. To the left of the latter are the dim outlines of the Lincoln and Chanin Buildings.

May 3, 1930
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

Lexington Avenue, west side, south from E. 49th Street, as viewed from the Hotel Beverly at the N.E. corner of 50th Street. Constructional details seen are for the new Waldorf-Astoria. Across same appears the 14 story Barclay. This is at the S.W. corner. Above this is the towering Grand Central Building. To the left of the latter are the dim outlines of the Lincoln and Chanin Buildings.

May 3, 1930
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr
